content: I am a physics PhD student in Berkeley, CA, working on building quantum processors out of superconducting qubits. At Berkeley, I work in the Quantum Nanoelectronics Lab under the guidance of Dr. Irfan Siddiqi. I received my Master’s studying ultracold atoms with Dr. Martin Zwierlein at MIT.
summary: I am a physics PhD student in Berkeley, CA, working on building quantum processors out of superconducting qubits. At Berkeley, I work in the Quantum Nanoelectronics Lab under the guidance of Dr. Irfan Siddiqi. I received my Master’s studying ultracold atoms with Dr. Martin Zwierlein at MIT.
Tutorial on HMC, which uses Hamiltonian dynamics to efficiently sample from high-dimensional distributions
title: Intro to Sampling using Hamiltonian Monte-Carlo

summary: Notes on the 2018 paper Adversarial Spheres, which shows how adversarial examples may be inevitable given an imperfect, high-dimensional classifier
title: Reading Group: Adversarial Spheres

summary: Uses basic results from undergraduate quantum and statistical mechanics classes to explore the Gaussian Orthogonal Ensemble, one of the canonical probability distributions studied in random matrix theory.
title: Random matrix theory via undergrad physics

summary: A tutorial notebook written for fellow experimentalists in quantum information to explore some properties of random quantum states.
title: Properties of Haar-Random Quantum States
